page.title: 11EARLY HISTORY OF KETTLEWELL
page.content: People have lived in Wharfedale since the Bronze Age. In the 8th Century Anglian farmers settled here, calling it "Cetel Wella", a bubbling spring, or stream. Mediaeval Kettlewell had a fine market, with a charter in 1320. The surrounding area was owned by the monasteries and managed as vast sheep estates. Livestock was sold at the weekly market and Autumn fair. In the 16th and 17th Centuries the farmers became freeholders or yeomen with new wealth to rebuild farm houses, still in use today. From 1800, leadmining grew in importance, with hundreds of tons of lead ore mined at Dowber Gill and smelted in the village. Smaller cottages were built to house miners and their families. Lime kilns were built in the 18th Centuries.
